conclusion: Objects A and B are pieces of fabric that are initially suspended in the air.
Under fabric A are blocks C (short gray block) and D (taller green block); under fabric B are blocks E (tall green block) and F (blue block).
When the fabrics are released, gravity accelerates them downward.
The fabrics reach the tops of the blocks first, collide, lose speed, and begin to drape.
Fabric A spreads over the tops of C and D, then sags between and around them until it either touches the tabletop or reaches equilibrium in mid-air.
Fabric B does the same over E and F.
Friction and the pins/weights sewn into the cloth corners keep each fabric from sliding off the blocks once the motion stops.
After a short time the system comes to rest: each cloth sits motionless, naturally draped over its corresponding pair of blocks.

Final answer: Both pieces of fabric will fall, hit the blocks underneath them, and then drape/hang around those blocks until they settle into a stable, motionless shape over C–D and over E–F, respectively.
